'''Calvin "Fuzz" Jones''' (June 9, 1926 {{spaced ndash}} August 9, 2010) was an American [[electric blues]] bassist and singer.  He worked with many blues musicians including [[Muddy Waters]], [[Howlin' Wolf]], [[the Legendary Blues Band]], [[Mississippi Heat]], [[James Cotton]], [[Luther Johnson (Guitar Junior)|Luther "Guitar Junior" Johnson]], [[Little Walter]], [[Elmore James]], and [[Cassandra Wilson]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/calvin-quot-fuzz-quot-jones-mn0000945718 |title=Calvin "Fuzz" Jones - Music Biography, Credits and Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref><ref name="About">{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/b/2010/08/11/blues-legend-calvin-fuzz-jones-r-i-p.htm |title=Blues Legend Calvin "Fuzz" Jones, R.I.P |publisher=Blues.about.com |date=2010-08-11 |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref>

He contributed to the collaborative 1996 album, ''Eye to Eye'', which also featured [[Pinetop Perkins]], [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]], [[Ronnie Earl]] and [[Bruce Katz]].<ref name="Eye">{{cite web|last=Yanow |first=Scott |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/eye-to-eye-mw0000081542 |title=Eye to Eye - Calvin "Fuzz" Jones, Pinetop Perkins, Ronnie Earl, Willie "Big Eyes" Smith : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Jones was born in [[Greenwood, Mississippi|Greenwood]], [[Mississippi]], United States.<ref name="AMG"/> He was raised on a farm close to  [[Inverness, Mississippi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deltaboogie.grou.ps/blogs/item/calvin-quotfuzzquot-jones |title=Calvin "Fuzz" Jones | Blogs | Delta Boogie Network |publisher=Deltaboogie.grou.ps |date= |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref> In his childhood he learned to play both the violin and acoustic bass, before graduating to the electric bass guitar, which became his [[Musical instrument|instrument]] of choice.<ref name="AMG"/>  

In 1970, he joined the backing band of [[Muddy Waters]], and played with them until 1980.<ref name="Museum">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.deltabluesmuseum.org/news-rip_calvin_fuzz_jones.asp |title=Calvin "Fuzz" Jones - Rest in Peace - Delta Blues Museum, Clarksdale MS |publisher=Deltabluesmuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref> He played on albums such as ''They Call Me Muddy Waters'' (1971),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/they-call-me-muddy-waters-i-mw0000654553/credits |title=They Call Me Muddy Waters [I] - Muddy Waters : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref> ''[[Muddy "Mississippi" Waters – Live]]'' (1979),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/muddy-mississippi-waters-live-mw0000206355/credits |title=Muddy "Mississippi" Waters Live - Muddy Waters : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref>  and ''[[King Bee (album)|King Bee]]'' (1981).<ref name="About"/>  He became known for his "strong electric bass playing, rocking stage presence, deep blues singing, and the friendly laugh and smile he had for all".<ref name="juke blues">{{cite journal |last1=Margolin |first1=Bob|year=2010 |title= Obituaries: Calvin "Fuzz" Jones|journal= Juke Blues|issue= 70|pages=58 |publisher= Juke Blues Magazine|doi= |url= |accessdate=17 March 2013}}</ref>

In the 1980 film, ''[[The Blues Brothers (film)|The Blues Brothers]]'', Jones appeared as the bassist in the blues band on [[Maxwell Street]],  [[Chicago]], outside the Soul Food Cafe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesbrotherscentral.com/profiles/calvin-fuzz-jones/ |title=Calvin 'Fuzz' Jones |publisher=Blues Brothers Central |date=1926-06-09 |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref> The same year, Jones, along with others from Muddy Waters backing group, formed [[the Legendary Blues Band]].  They recorded seven albums with Jones playing bass, and occasionally providing vocals, before splitting up in 1993.<ref name="AMG"/>

Jones also recorded with [[Mississippi Heat]] appearing on their debut album, ''Straight From The Heart'' (1993).  His contributed both bass guitar duties as well as singing lead vocal on one track, "Ruby Mae".  The song was written by fellow band member [[Billy Flynn (musician)|Billy Flynn]] for Jones wife, Ruby Mae Jones.<ref name="AMG"/> He also appeared at the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]] that year.

Jones also had spells playing with the Muddy Waters Tribute Band (''You Gonna Miss Me (When I'm Dead & Gone)'', 1997),<ref name="About"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Hoffman |first=Steve |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/you-gonna-miss-me-when-im-dead-gone-mw0000648320 |title=You Gonna Miss Me (When I'm Dead & Gone) - Muddy Waters Tribute Band : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1997-01-21 |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref> the Howlin' Wolf Tribute Band, and the Jelly Roll All-Stars.<ref name="AMG"/> In 1999, Jones played on [[Barrelhouse Chuck]]'s debut album, ''Salute to Sunnyland Slim''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Simmons |first=Earl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/salute-to-sunnyland-slim-mw0000242533 |title=Salute to Sunnyland Slim - Barrelhouse Chuck : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1999-02-16 |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref> He backed [[Cassandra Wilson]] on her 2003 album, ''[[Glamoured]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/glamoured-mw0000692161/credits |title=Glamoured - Cassandra Wilson : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=2003-10-07 |accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref> as well as her recording of "Vietnam Blues, the latter written by [[J. B. Lenoir]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In later years, Jones lived in [[Senatobia, Mississippi]].<ref name="juke blues"/> He died in [[Southaven, Mississippi]], from complications of [[lung cancer]] and a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]], in August 2010, aged 84.<ref name="About"/>
